text: MANY of us have first found our way into the Realm of Romance, properly
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: so called, through the pages of a little crimson clad volume of the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: _Bibliothèque Elzevirienne_. {1}  Its last pages contain the charming
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Cante-Fable of _Aucassin et Nicolete_, which Mr. Walter Pater’s praises
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: and Mr. Andrew Lang’s brilliant version have made familiar to all lovers
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: of letters.  But the same volume contains four other tales, equally
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: charming in their way, which Mr. William Morris has now made part of
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: English literature by writing them out again for us in English,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: reproducing, as his alone can do of living men’s, the tone, the colour,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: the charm of the Middle Ages.  His versions have appeared in three
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: successive issues of the Kelmscott Press, which have been eagerly snapped
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: up by the lovers of good books.  It seemed a pity that these cameos of
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: romance should suffer the same fate as Mr. Lang’s version of _Aucassin et
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Nicolete_, which has been swept off the face of the earth by the Charge
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: of the Six Hundred, who were lucky enough to obtain copies of the only
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: edition of that little masterpiece of translation.  Mr. Morris has,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: therefore, consented to allow his versions of the Romances to be combined
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: into one volume in a form not unworthy of their excellence but more
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: accessible to those lovers of books whose purses have a habit of varying
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: in inverse proportion to the amount of their love.  He has honoured me by
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: asking me to introduce them to that wider public to which they now make
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: their appeal.

text: ALMOST all literary roads lead back to Greece.  Obscure as still remains
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: the origin of that _genre_ of romance to which the tales before us
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: belong, there is little doubt that their models, if not their originals,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: were once extant at Constantinople.  Though in no single instance has the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Greek original been discovered of any of these romances, the mere name of
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: their heroes would be in most cases sufficient to prove their Hellenic or
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Byzantine origin.  Heracles, Athis, Porphirias, Parthenopeus, Hippomedon,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Protesilaus, Cliges, Cleomades, Clarus, Berinus—names such as these can
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: come but from one quarter of Europe, and it is as easy to guess how and
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: when they came as whence.  The first two crusades brought the flower of
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: European chivalry to Constantinople and restored that spiritual union
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: between Eastern and Western Christendom that had been interrupted by the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: great schism of the Greek and Roman Churches.  The crusaders came mostly
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: from the Lands of Romance.  Permanent bonds of culture began to be formed
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: between the extreme East and the extreme West of Europe by intermarriage,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: by commerce, by the admission of the nobles of Byzantium within the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: orders of chivalry.  These ties went on increasing throughout the twelfth
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: century till they culminated at its close with the foundation of the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Latin kingdom of Constantinople.  In European literature these historic
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: events are represented by the class of romances represented in this
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: volume, which all trace back to versions in verse of the twelfth century,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: though they were done into prose somewhere in Picardy during the course
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: of the next century.  Daphnis and Chloe, one might say, had revived after
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: a sleep of 700 years, and donned the garb and spoke the tongue of
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Romance.

text: The very first of our tales illustrates admirably the general course of
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: their history.  It is, in effect, a folk etymology of the name of the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: great capital of the Eastern Empire.  Constantinople, so runs the tale,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: received that name instead of Byzantium, because of the remarkable career
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: of one of its former rulers, Coustans.  M. Wesselovsky has published in
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: _Romania_ (vi. 1. seq.) the _Dit de l’empereur Constant_, the verse
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: original of the story before us, and in this occur the lines—
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Pour ce que si _nobles_ estoit
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Et que nobles œvres faisoit
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: L’appielloient _Constant le noble_
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Et pour çou ot _Constantinnoble_
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Li cytés de Bissence a non.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: From which it would appear that we are mistaken in thinking of the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: capital of Turkey as the “City of Constantine,” whereas it is rather
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Constant the Noble, and the name Coustant is further explained as
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: “costing” too much.  Constantinople, therefore, is the city that costs
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: too much, according to the prophetic etymology of the folk.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: The only historic personage with whom this Coustant can be identified is
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Constantius Chlorus, the father of Constantine the Great and the husband
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: of St. Helena, to whom legend ascribes the discovery of the Holy Rood.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: But the Coustans of our story never lived or ruled on land or sea, and
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: his predecessor, Muselinus, is altogether unknown to Byzantine annals,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: while their interlaced history reads more like a page of the _Arabian
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Nights_ than of Gibbon.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: But such a legend could scarcely have arisen elsewhere than at
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Constantinople.  It is one of those fables that the disinherited folk
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: have at all times invented to solace themselves for their disinherison.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: The sudden and fated rise of one of the folk to the heights of power
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: occurs sufficiently often to afford material for the day dreams of
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: ambitious youth.  There is even a popular tendency to attribute a lowly
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: origin to all favourites of fortune, as witness the legends that have
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: grown up about the early careers of Beckett, Whittington, Wolsey, none of
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: whom was as ill-born as popular tradition asserts.  Yet such legends
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: invariably grow up in the country of their heroes, which is the only one
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: sufficiently interested in their career, so far as the common people are
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: concerned.  Hence the very nature of our story would cause us to locate
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: its origin on the banks of the Bosphorus.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: But once originated in this manner, there is no limit to the travels it
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: may take.  Curiously enough, the very legend before us in all its details
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: has found a home among the English peasantry.  The Rev. S. Baring-Gould
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: collected in Yorkshire a story which he contributed to Henderson’s
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: _Folklore of the Northern Counties_, and entitled _The Fish and the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Ring_. {2}  In this legend a girl comes as the unwelcome sixth of the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: family of a very poor man who lived under the shadow of York Minster.  A
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Knight, riding by on the day of her birth, discovers, by consultation of
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: the Book of Fate, that she was destined to marry his son.  He offers to
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: adopt her, and throws her into the River Ouse.  A fisherman saves her,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: and she is again discovered after many years by the Knight, who learns
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: what Fate has still in store for his son.  He sends her to his brother at
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Scarborough with a fatal letter, ordering him to put her to death.  But
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: on the way she is seized by a band of robbers, who read the letter and
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: replace it by one ordering the Baron’s son to be married to her
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: immediately on her arrival.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: When the Baron discovers that he has not been able to evade the decree of
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: fate he still persists in his persecution, and taking a ring from his
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: finger throws it into the sea, saying that the girl shall never live with
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: his son till she can show him that ring.  She wanders about and becomes a
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: scullery-maid at a great castle, and one day when the Baron is dining at
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: the castle, while cleaning a great fish she finds his ring, and all ends
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: happily.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Now on the east wall of the chancel of Stepney Church there is a monument
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: erected to Dame Rebecca Berry, wife of Thomas Elton, of Stratford, Bow,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: and relict of Sir John Berry, 1696.  The arms on the monument are thus
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: blazoned by heralds . . . .  “Paly of six on a bend three mullets (Elton)
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: impaling a fish, and in the dexter chief point an annulet between two
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: bends wavy.”  The reference in the impalement of the blazon is obvious.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: A local tradition confidently identifies Dame Berry as the heroine of the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Yorkshire legend, though of course it is ignorant of her connection with
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: the etymology of Constantinople.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Now this tale, or the first half of it, is but a Yorkshire variant of one
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: spread throughout Europe.  The opening of the twenty-ninth story of the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: collection of the Brothers Grimm, and entitled _The Devil with the Three
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Golden Hairs_, is exactly the same, and in their Notes they give
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: references to many similar European folk-tales.  The story is found in
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Modern Greece (Von Hahn, No. XX.), and it is, therefore, possible that
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: the story of King Coustans is the adaptation of a Greek folk-tale for the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: purposes of a Folk Etymology.  But the letter, “On delivery, please kill
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: bearer,” is scarcely likely to have occurred twice to the popular
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: imagination, and one is almost brought to the conclusion that the romance
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: before us was itself either directly or indirectly the source of all the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: European Folk-tales in which the letter “To kill bearer” occurs.  And as
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: we have before traced the Romance back to Constantinople, one is further
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: tempted to trace back the Letter itself to a reminiscence of Homer’s
title: Old French Romances, Done into English

text: I have said above that no Greek original of any of these Romances has
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: rate get within appreciable distance of it.  As recently as 1895 a
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: _Byzantinische Zeitschrift_, the existence of an Ethiopic and of an
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: catalogues a description of an illuminated Ethiopic MS., once belonging
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: of the illustrations he was enabled to identify as the story of “The Man

author: Morris, William

text: born to be King.”  His name in the Ethiopic version is Thalassion, or

author: Morris, William

text: Ethiopic words to that effect, and the Greek _provenance_ of the story is

author: Morris, William

text: thereby established.  Dr. Kuhn was also successful in finding an Arabic

author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: identity of names, bring Mr. Morris in guilty of a knowledge of Ethiopic.

text: So much for the origin of our tales.  Yet who cares for origins nowadays?
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: We are all democrats now, and a tale, like a man, is welcomed for its
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: merits and not for its pedigree.  Yet even democracy must own, that
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: pedigree often leaves its trace in style and manner, and certainly the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: tales before us owe some of their charm to their lineage.  “Out of
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Byzantium by Old France” is a good strain by which to produce
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: thoroughbred romance.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Certainly we breathe the very air of romance in these stories.  There is
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: none of your modern priggish care for the state of your soul.  Men take
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: rank according to their might, women are valued for their beauty alone.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Adventures are to the adventurous, and the world is full of them.  Every
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: place but that in which one is born is equally strange and wondrous.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Once beyond the bounds of the city walls and none knows what may happen.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: We have stepped forth into the Land of Faerie, but at least we are in the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: open air.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Mr. Pater seems to regard our stories as being a premonition of the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: freedom and gaiety of the Renaissance rather than as especially
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: characteristic of the times of Romance.  All that one need remark upon
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: such misconception is that it only proves that Mr. Pater knew less of
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Romance Literature than he did of his favourite subject.  The freshness,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: the gaiety, the direct outlook into life are peculiar neither to Romance
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: nor Renaissance; their real source was the _esprit Gaulois_.  But the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: unquestioning, if somewhat external, piety, the immutability of the caste
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: system, the spirit of adventure, the frankly physical love of woman, the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: large childlike wonder, these are of the essence of Romance, and they are
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: fully represented in the tales before us.  Wonder and reverence, are not
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: these the parents of Romance?  Intelligent curiosity and intellectual
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: doubt—those are what the Renaissance brought.  Without indulging in
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: invidious comparisons between the relative value of these gifts, I would
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: turn back to our stories with the remark that much of the wonder which
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: they exhibit is due to the vague localisation which runs through them.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Rome, Paris, Byzantium, form spots of light on the mediæval map, but all
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: between is in the dim obscure where anything may occur, and the brave man

author: Morris, William

text: moves about with his life in his hands.

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: When the damsel had heard that, she said that would be good to do.  “But,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Lady, how wilt thou have the seal of thy father?”  “Full well,” said the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Maiden, “for my father delivered to me four pair of scrolls, sealed of
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: his seal thereon; he hath written nought therein; and I will write all
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: that I will.”  “Lady,” said she, “thou hast said full well; but do it
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: speedily, and haste thee ere he awakeneth.”  “So will I,” said the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Maiden.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Then the fair Maiden, the daughter of the Emperor, went to her coffers,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: and drew thereout one of the said scrolls sealed, which her father had
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: left her, that she might borrow moneys thereby, if so she would.  For
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: ever was the Emperor and his folk in war, whereas he had neighbours right
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: felon, and exceeding mighty, whose land marched upon his.  So the Maiden
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: wrote the letter in this wise:
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: “I King Musselin, Emperor of Greece and of Byzance the city, to my
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Burgreve of Byzance greeting.  I command thee that the bearer of this
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: letter ye give to my fair daughter in marriage according to our law;
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: whereas I have heard and wot soothly that he is a high person, and well
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: worthy to have my daughter.  And thereto make ye great joy and great
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: feast to all them of my city and of all my land.”
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: In such wise wrote and said the letter of the fair daughter of the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Emperor; and when she had written the said letter, she went back to the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: garden, she and her fellow together, and found that one yet asleep, and
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: they put the letter into his pouch.  And then they began to sing and make
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: noise to awaken him.  So he awoke anon, and was all astonied at the fair
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Maiden, the daughter of the Emperor, and the other one her fellow, who
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: came before him; and the fair Maiden, daughter of the Emperor, greeted
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: him; and he greeted her again right debonairly.  Then she asked of him
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: what he was, and whither he went; and he said that he bore a letter to
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: the Burgreve, which the Emperor sent by him; and the Maiden said that she
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: would bring him straightway whereas was the Burgreve.  Therewith she took
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: him by the hand, and brought him to the palace, where there was much
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: folk, who all rose against the Maiden, as to her who was their Lady.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Now the Maiden demanded the Burgreve, and they told her that he was in a
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: chamber; so thither she led the lad, and the lad delivered the letter,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: and said that the Emperor greeted him.  But the Burgreve made great joy
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: of the lad, and kissed the hand of him.  The Maiden opened the pouch, and
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: fell a-kissing the letter and the seal of her father for joy’s sake,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: whereas she had not heard tidings of him a great while.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Thereafter she said to the Burgreve that she would hearken the letter in
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: privy council, even as if she wotted nought thereof; and the Burgreve
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: said that that were good to do.  Then went the Burgreve and the Maiden
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: into a chamber, and the Maiden unfolded the letter and read it to the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Burgreve, and made semblance of wondering exceedingly; and the Burgreve
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: said to her, “Lady, it behoveth to do the will of my lord thy father, for
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: otherwise we shall be blamed exceedingly.”  The Maiden answered him: “And
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: how can this be, that I should be wedded without my lord my father?  A
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: strange thing it would be, and I will do it in no manner.”
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: “Ha, Lady!” said the Burgreve, “what is that thou sayest?  Thy father has
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: bidden thus by his letter, and it behoveth not to gainsay.”
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: “Sir,” said the Maiden, (unto whom it was late till the thing were done)
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: “thou shalt speak unto the barons and mighty men of this realm, and take
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: counsel thereof.  And if they be of accord thereto, I am she who will not
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: go against it.”  Then the Burgreve said that she spake well and as one
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: wise.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Then spake the Burgreve to the barons, I and showed them the letter, and
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: they accorded all to that that the matter of the letter must be
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: accomplished, and the will of the Emperor done.  Then they wedded the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: fair youth Coustans, according to the paynim law, unto the fair daughter
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: of the Emperor; and the wedding endured for fifteen days: and such great
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: joy was there at Byzance that it was exceeding, and folk did no work in
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: the city, save eating and drinking and making merry.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Long while abode the Emperor in the land whereas he was: and when he had
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: done his business, he went his ways back towards Byzance; and whenas he
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: was but anigh two journeys thence, came to him a message of the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: messengers who came from Byzance.  The Emperor asked of him what they did
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: in the city; and the varlet said that they were making exceeding good
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: cheer of eating and drinking and taking their ease, and that no work had
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: they done therein these fifteen days.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: “And wherefore is that?” said the Emperor.  “Wherefore, Sir!  Wot ye not
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: well thereof?”  “Nay, forsooth,” said the Emperor, “but tell me
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: wherefore.”
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: “Sir,” said the varlet, “thou sentest a youngling, exceeding fair, to thy
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Burgreve, and badest him by thy letter to wed him to thy daughter the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: fair, and that he should be emperor after thee, whereas he was a man
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: right high, and well worthy to have her.  But thy daughter would not take
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: that before that the Burgreve should have spoken to the barons.  And he
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: spake to all them, and showed them thy letter; and they said that it
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: behoved to do thy commandment.  And when thy daughter saw that they were
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: all of one accord thereon, she durst not go against them, but yea-said
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: it.  Even in such wise hath thy daughter been wedded, and such joy has
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: been in the city as none might wish it better.”
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: The Emperor, when he heard the messenger speak thus, was all astonied,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: and thought much of this matter; and he asked of the varlet how long it
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: was since the lad had wedded his daughter, and whether or no he had lain
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: by her?
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: “Sir,” said the varlet, “yea; and she may well be big by now; because it
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: is more than three weeks since he hath wedded her.”  “Forsooth,” said the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Emperor, “in a good hour be it! for since it is so, it behoveth me to
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: abide it, since no other it may be.”
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: So far rode the Emperor till he came to Byzance, whereas they made him
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: much fair feast; and his fair daughter came to meet him, and her husband
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Coustans, who was so fair a child that none might better be.  The
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Emperor, who was a wise man, made of them much great joy, and laid his
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: two hands upon their two heads, and held them there a great while; which
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: is the manner of benison amongst the paynims.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: That night thought the Emperor much on this marvel, how it could have
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: come about; and so much he pondered it, that he wotted full well that it
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: had been because of his daughter.  So he had no will to gain-say her, but
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: he demanded to see the letter which he had sent, and they showed it unto
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: him, and he saw his seal hanging thereto, and saw the letter which was
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: written; and by the manner whereby the thing had been done, he said to
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: himself that he had striven against the things which behoved to be.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Thereafter, the Emperor made Coustans a knight, even his new son who was
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: wedded unto his daughter, and he gave and granted to him all the whole
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: land after his death.  And the said Coustans bore him well and wisely, as
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: a good knight, and a valiant and hardy, and defended him full well
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: against his enemies.  No long time wore ere his lord the Emperor died,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: and his service was done much richly, after the paynim law.  Then was
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Coustans emperor, and he loved and honoured much the Abbot who had
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: nourished him, and he made him his very master.  And the Emperor
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Coustans, by the counsel of the Abbot, and the will of God the all
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: mighty, did do christen his wife, and all they of that land were
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: converted to the law of Jesus Christ.  And the Emperor Coustans begot on
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: his wife an heir male, who had to name Constantine, who was thereafter a
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: prudhomme much great.  And thereafter was the city called Constantinople,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: because of his father, Coustans, who costed so much, but aforetime was it
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: called Byzance.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Here withal endeth the Story of King Coustans the Emperor.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Morris.

text: The Friendship of Amis and Amile
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English

text: IN the time of Pepin King of France was a child born in the Castle of
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Bericain of a noble father of Alemaine who was of great holiness.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: The father and the mother promised to God, and Saint Peter and Saint
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Paul, whereas they had none other child, that if God gave it life, they
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: would bear it to Rome to baptism.  At the same time came a vision to a
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Count of Alverne, whose wife was big with child, whereby it seemed that
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: the Apostle of Rome was baptizing many children in his palace and
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: confirming them with chrism.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: So when the Count was awaken he sought of many wise folk what might
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: signify that which he had seen in the dream.  And when his vision was
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: uncovered, a wise man and ancient bespake him by the counsel of God:
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: “Make great joy, Count, for there shall be born to thee a son full of
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: great prowess and of great holiness; and him thou shalt let bear to Rome
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: and let baptize him by the Apostle.”
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Thereof great joy made the Count, and he and his folk praised the counsel
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: of the elder.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: The child was born and dearly fostered, and when he had two years, and
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: the father after his purpose was bearing him to Rome, he came to the city
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: of Lucca.  And therein he found a noble man of Almaine who was wending
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Romeward and bearing his son to baptism.  They greeted one the other, and
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: each asked other who he was and what he sought, and when they found
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: themselves to be of one purpose they joined company in all friendliness
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: and entered Rome together.  And the two children fell to loving one
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: another so sorely that one would not eat without the other, they lived of
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: one victual, and lay in one bed.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: In this wise the fathers brought them before the Apostle at Rome, and
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: spake to him: “Holy Father, whom we know and believe to be in the place
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: of Saint Peter the Apostle, the Count of Alverne, and a noble knight of
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Bericain the Castle, beseech your Holiness that ye would deign to baptize
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: their sons which they have brought from far away, and that ye would take
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: their little offering from their hands.”
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: And the Apostle answered them: “I hold your gifts for right acceptable,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: but they are not to me of much necessity; give them to the poor, who have
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: need thereof.  The infants will I baptize with a good will, that the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Father, the Son, and the Holy Ghost may embrace them in the love of the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Holy Trinity.”
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Forthwith then the Apostle baptized them in the Church of the Holy
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Saviour, and laid for name on the son of the Count, Amile, and on the son
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: of the Knight, Amis; and many a knight of Rome held them at the font with
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: mickle joy, and raised them aloft even as God would.  And the office of
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Baptism done, the Apostle bade bring two hanaps of tree dight with gold
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: and precious stones, side and wide alike, and of like fashion, and gave
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: them to the bairns and said: “Take these gifts in token that I have
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: baptized you in the Church of the Holy Saviour.”  Which gifts they took
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: joyfully and thanked him much, and betook them thence home in all
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: joyance.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: To the child of Bericain did God give so great wisdom, that one might
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: trow that he were another Solomon; and when he was of the age of thirty
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: years a fever took his father, and he fell to admonishing his son in such
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: like words: “Fair son, well beloved, it behoveth me presently to die, and
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: thou shalt abide and be thine own master.  Now firstly, fair son, keep
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: thou the commandments of God; the chivalry of Jesus Christ do thou.  Keep
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: thou faith to thy lords, and give aid to thy fellows and friends.  Defend
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: the widows and orphans.  Uphold the poor and needy: and all days hold thy
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: last day in memory.  Forget not the fellowship and friendship of the son
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: of the Count of Alverne, whereas the Apostle of Rome on one day baptized
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: you both, and with one gift honoured you.  Ye be alike of beauty, of
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: fashion, and stature, and whoso should see you, would deem you to be
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: brethren.”
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: So having finished these words, and received his Saviour, he departed in
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: our Lord, and his son did do bury him, and did do render him his service,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: even as one should do for the dead.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: After the death of his father evil folk bore envy against him, and did
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: him many a scathe, and grieved him sorely; but he loved them all and
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: suffered whatsoever they did to him.  What more may I tell you, save that
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: they cast him and his folk out of the heritage of his fathers, and chased
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: him forth out of his castle.  So when he bethought him of the commandment
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: of his father, he said to them who went in his company: “The wicked have
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: wrongfully cast me forth out of mine heritage: yet have I good hope in
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: our Lord that he will help me; go we now to the Court of the Count Amile,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: who was my friend and my fellow.  May-happen he will make us rich with

title: Old French Romances, Done into English

text: That word pleased them, and they I held the bridal with mickle joy.  But

title: Old French Romances, Done into English

title: Old French Romances, Done into English

text: Now by this time had Amile been a-seeking for Amis two years past without
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: ceasing.  And whenas Amile drew nigh to Paris he found a pilgrim and
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: asked if he had seen Amis whom men had chased out of his land; and that
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: one said nay, he had not.  But Amile did off his coat and gave it to the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: no-whither Amis his fellow.

author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: But the pilgrim went his ways forthwith, and about vespers happened on
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Amis, and they greeted each the other.  And Amis said to the pilgrim, had
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: he seen or heard tidings in any land of Amile, son of the Count of
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Alverne.  And the pilgrim answered him all marvelling: “Who art thou,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Knight, who thus mockest a pilgrim?  Thou seemest to me that Amile who
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: this day asked of me if I had seen Amis his fellow.  I wot not for why
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: thou hast changed thy garments, thy folk, thine horses, and thine arms.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: gavest me this coat.”
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: “Trouble not thine heart,” said Amis, “I am not he whom thou deemest; but
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: him pray our Lord to give him to find Amile.  And the pilgrim said: “Go
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: thy ways forthright to Paris, and I trow that thou shalt find him whom
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: thou seekest so sore longing.”  And therewith Aims went his ways full
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: eagerly.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Now on the morrow Amile was already departed from Paris, and was sitting
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: at meat with his knights hard by the water of Seine in a flowery meadow.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: And when they saw Amis coming with his fellows all armed, they rose up
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: and armed them, and so went forth before them; and Amis said to his
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: fellows: “I see French knights who come against us in arms.  Now fight
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: hardily and defend your lives.  If we may escape this peril, then shall
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: we go with great joy to Paris, and thereto shall we be received with high
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: favour at the Court of the King.”
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Then were the reins let loose and the spears shaken aloft, and the swords
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: drawn on either side, in such wise that no semblance was there that any
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: should escape alive.  But God the all mighty who seeth all, and who
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: setteth an end to the toil of the righteous, did to hold aback them of
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: one part and of the other when they were now hard on each other, for then
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: said Amis: “Who are ye knights, who have will to slay Amis the exile and
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: his fellows?”  At that voice Amile knew Amis his fellow and said: “O thou
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Amis most well beloved, rest from my travail, I am Amile, son of the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Count of Alverne, who have not ceased to seek thee for two whole years.”
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: And therewith they lighted down from their horses, and embraced and
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: kissed each other, and gave thanks to God of that they were found.  And
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: they swore fealty and friendship and fellowship perpetual, the one to the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: other, on the sword of Amile, wherein were relics.  Thence went they all
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: together to the Court of Charles, King of France; there might men behold
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: them young, well attempered, wise, fair, and of like fashion and visage,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: loved of all and honoured.  And the King received them much joyously, and
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: made of Amis his treasurer, and of Amile his server.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: But when they had abided thus three years, Amis said unto Amile: “Fair
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: sweet fellow, I desire sore to go see my wife whom I have left behind;
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: and I will return the soonest that I may; and do thou abide at the Court.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: But keep thee well from touching the daughter of the King; and above all
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: things beware of Arderi the felon.”  Amile answered him: “I will take
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: heed of thy commandment; but betake thee back hither so soon as thou
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: mayest.”
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Thuswise departed Amis.  But Amile cast his eyes upon the King’s
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: daughter, and knew her so soon as he might; and right soon forgat he the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: commandment and the teaching of Amis his fellow.  Yet is not this
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: adventure strange, whereas he was no holier than David, nor wiser than
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Solomon.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Amidst these things Arderi the traitor, who bore him envy, came to him
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: and said: “Thou wottest not, fellow, thou wottest not, how Amis hath
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: will swear the same to thee on the holy Gospel.”  And so when that was
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: done Amile doubted not to lay bare his secret to Arderi.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: But whenas Amile was a-giving water to the King to wash his hands withal,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: the false Arderi said to the King: “Take thou no water from this evil
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: man, sir King: for he is more worthy of death than of life, whereas he
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: hath taken from the Queen’s Daughter the flower of her virginity.”  But
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: word; but the benign King lifted him up again, and said to him: “Rise up,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Amile, and have no fear, and defend thee of this blame.”  So he lifted
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: himself up and said: “Have no will to trow, sire, in the lies of Arderi
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: the traitor, for I wot that thou art a rightwise judge, and that thou
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: turnest not from the right way, neither for love nor for hatred.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Wherefore I pray thee that thou give me frist of counsel; and that I may
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: purge me of this guilt before thee, and do the battle against Arderi the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: traitor, and make him convict of his lies before all the Court.”
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: and that then they should come before him for to do their devoir; and
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: they came before the King at the term which he had given them.  Arderi
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: would be for him saving Hildegarde the Queen, who took up the cause for
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: came not back by the term established, she should be lacking all days of
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: the bed of the King.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: But when Amile went to seek counsel, he happened on Amis, his fellow, who
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: was betaking him to the King’s Court; and Amile lighted down from his
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: horse, and cast himself at the feet of his fellow, and said: “O thou, the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: the false Arderi.”
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Then said Amis, sighing: “Leave we here our folk, end enter into this
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: wood to lay bare our secret.”  And Amis fell to blaming Amile, and said:
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: will do the battle for thee against the traitor.”  And Amile answered:
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: “How may I go into thine house, who have no knowledge of thy wife and thy
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: folk, and have never seen them face to face?”  But Amis said to him: “Go
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: in all safety, and seek wisely to know them: but take good heed that thou
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: touch not my wife.”
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: the house of his fellow in the semblance of Amis.  But the wife of Amis,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: when she saw him betake him thither, ran to embrace him, whom she deemed
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: was her husband, and would have kissed him.  But he said: “Flee thou from
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: before me, for I have greater need to lament than to play; whereas, since
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: I departed from thee, I have suffered adversity full sore, and yet have
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: to suffer.”
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: betwixt the two of them, and said to the woman: “Take heed that thou
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: daughter.”
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English

author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: whereas God may peradventure of His great mercy purvey for my poverty.”
title: Old French Romances, Done into English

title: Old French Romances, Done into English

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: sergeants.

text: But in the space of three years thereafter was so great famine in the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: city, that the father had will to thrust the son away from his house.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
