text: Then spake Azones and Horatus to Amis, and said: “Fair sir, thou wottest
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: how feally we have served thee sithence the death of thy father unto this
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: day, and that we have never trespassed against thy commandment.  But now
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: we may no longer abide with thee, whereas we have no will to perish of
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: hunger: wherefore we pray thee give us leave to escape this mortal
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: pestilence.”
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Then Amis answered them weeping: “O ye fair sons, and not sergeants, my
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: only comfort, I pray you for God’s sake that ye leave me not here, but
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: bear me to the city of the Count Amile my fellow.”
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: And they who would well obey his commandments, bore him thither whereas
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: was Amile; and there they fell to sounding on their tartavelles before
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: the Court of Amile, even as mesel folk be wont to do.  And when Amile
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: heard the sound thereof he bade a sergeant of his to bear to the sick man
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: of bread and of flesh, and therewithal his hanap, which was given to him
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: at Rome, full of good wine: and when the sergeant had done his
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: commandment he said to him when he came again: “By the faith which I owe
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: thee, sir, if I held not thine hanap in my hand, I had deemed that it was
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: even that which the sick man had; for one and the same be they of
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: greatness and of fashion.”  Then said Amile: “Go speedily and lead him
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: hither to me.”
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: But when he was before his fellow he asked of him who he was, and how he
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: had gotten that hanap.  Said he: “I am of Bericain the Castle, and the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: hanap was given me by the Apostle of Rome, when he baptized me.”
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: And when Amile heard that, he knew that it was Amis his fellow who had
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: delivered him from death, and given him to wife the King’s Daughter of
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: France; straightway he cast himself upon him and fell to crying out
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: strongly, and to weeping and lamenting, and to kissing and embracing him.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: And when his wife heard the same, she ran thereto all dishevelled, and
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: making great dole, whereas she had in memory of how he had slain Arderi.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: And straightway they laid him in a very fair bed, and said to him: “Abide
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: with us, fair sir, until that God shall do his will of thee, for
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: whatsoever we have is for thee to deal with.”  And he abode with them,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: and his sergeants with him.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Now it befel on a night whenas Amis and Amile lay in one chamber without
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: other company, that God sent to Amis Raphael his angel, who said to him:
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: “Sleepest thou, Amis?”  And he, who deemed that Amile had called to him,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: answered: “I sleep not, fair sweet fellow.”  Then the angel said to him:
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: “Thou hast answered well, whereas thou art the fellow of the citizens of
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Heaven, and thou hast followed after Job, and Thoby in patience.  Now I
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: am Raphael, an angel of our Lord, and am come to tell thee of a medicine
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: for thine healing, whereas He hath heard thy prayers.  Thou shalt tell to
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Amile thy fellow, that he slay his two children and wash thee in their
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: blood, and thence thou shalt get thee the healing of thy body.”
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Then said Amis: “Never shall it be that my fellow be a manslayer for the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: healing of me.”  But the Angel said: “Yet even so it behoveth to do.”
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: And when he had so said, the Angel departed; and therewith Amile, as if
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: a-sleeping, heard those words, and awoke, and said: “What is it, fellow?
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: who hath spoken unto thee?”  And Amis answered that none had spoken: “But
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: I have prayed to our Lord according to my wont.”  Then Amile said: “Nay,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: it is not so; some one hath spoken to thee.”  Therewith he arose and went
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: to the door of the chamber, and found it shut, and said: “Tell me, fair
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: brother, who hath spoken to thee these words of the night?”
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Then Amis fell a-weeping sorely, and said to him that it was Raphael the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Angel of our Lord who had said to him: “Amis, our Lord biddeth that thou
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: tell Amile that he slay his two children, and wash thee with the blood of
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: them, and that then thou wilt be whole of thy meselry.”
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: But Amile was sore moved with these words, and said to him: “Amis, I have
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: given over to thee man-servant and maid-servant and all my goods, and now
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: thou feignest in fraud that the Angel hath spoken to thee that I slay my
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: two children!”  But forthwith Amis fell a-weeping, and said: “I wot that
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: I have spoken to thee things grievous, as one constrained, and now I pray
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: thee that thou cast me not out of thine house.”  And Amile said that he
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: had promised that he would hold him till the hour of his death: “But I
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: conjure thee by the faith which is betwixt thee and me, and by our
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: fellowship, and by the baptism which we took between me and thee at Rome,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: that thou tell me if it be man or Angel who hath said this to thee.”
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Then Amis answered: “As true as it was an Angel who spake to me this
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: night, so may God deliver me from mine infirmity.”
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Then Amile fell to weeping privily, and thinking in his heart: “This man
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: forsooth was apparelled before the King to die for me, and why should I
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: not slay my children for him; if he hath kept faith with me to the death,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: why keep I not faith?  Abraham was saved by faith, and by faith have the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: hallows vanquished kingdoms; and God saith in the Gospel: ‘That which ye
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: would that men should do unto you, do ye even so to them.’”
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: And Amile without more tarrying, went to the chamber of his wife, and
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: bade her go hear the service of our Lord; and the Countess gat her to the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: church even as she was wont.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Then the Count took his sword, and went to the bed where lay his
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: children, and found them sleeping, and he threw himself upon them, and
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: fell to weeping bitterly and said: “Who hath heard ever of a father who
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: of his own will hath slain his child?  Ah, alas my children!  I shall be
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: no more your father, but your cruel murderer!”  And therewith the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: children awoke because of the tears which fell on them from their father;
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: and the children, who looked on the face of their father, fell
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: a-laughing.  And whereas they were of the age of three years or
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: thereabout, their father said to them: “Your laughter shall be turned
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: into weeping, for now shall your innocent blood be shed.”
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: When he had so said he cut off their heads and then laid them out behind
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: the bed, and laid the heads to the bodies, and covered them over even as
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: they slept.  And with their blood which he received, he washed his
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: fellow, and said: “Sire God, Jesus Christ, who commandest men to keep
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: faith upon the earth, and who cleansest the mesel by thy word, deign thou
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: to cleanse my fellow, for the love of whom I have shed the blood of my
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: children.”
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Then was Amis cleansed of his meselry, and they gave thanks to our Lord
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: with great joy and said: “Blessed be God, the father of our Lord Jesus
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Christ, who healeth them that have hope in him.”
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: And Amile clad his fellow in his own right goodly raiment; and therewith
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: they went to the church to give thanks there, and the bells by the grace
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: of God rang of themselves.  And when the people of the city heard that,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: they ran all together toward that marvel.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Now the wife of the Count when she saw them both going together, fell to
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: asking which of the two was her husband and said: “I know well the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: raiment of these twain, but I wot not which is Amile.”
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: And the Count said: “I am Amile, and this my fellow is Amis, who is
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: whole.”  Then the Countess wondered, and said: “I see him all whole; but
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: much I desire to know whereby he is healed.”  “Render we thanks to our
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Lord,” said the Count, “nor disquiet us as to how it may be.”
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Now was come the hour of tierce, and neither the father nor the mother
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: was yet entered in to their children; but the father sighed grievously
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: for the death of his babes.  Then the Countess asked for her children to
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: make her joy, and the Count said: “Dame let be, let the children sleep!”
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Therewith he entered all alone to the children to weep over them, and he
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: found them playing in the bed; but the scars of their wounds showed about
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: the necks of each of them even as a red fillet.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Then he took them in his arms, and bore them to their mother, and said
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: “Make great joy, dame, whereas thy sons whom I had slain by the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: commandment of the Angel are alive again, and by their blood is Amis
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: cured and healed.”
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: And when the Countess heard it she said: “O thou, Count, why didst thou
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: not lead me with thee to receive the blood of my children, and I would
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: have washed therewith Amis thy fellow and my Lord?”
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Then said the Count: “Dame, let be these words; and let us be at the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: service of our Lord, who hath done such great wonders in our house.”
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Which thing they did even unto their death and held chastity.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: And they made great joy through that same city for ten days.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: But on the selfsame day that Amis was made whole, the devils bore off his
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: wife; they brake the neck of her, and bore away her soul.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: After these things Amis betook him to the Castle of Bericain and laid
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: siege before it; and abode there before so long, that they of the castle
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: rendered themselves to him.  He received them benignly, and pardoned them
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: their evil will; and from thenceforth he dwelt with them peaceably and he
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: held with him the elder son of Amile, and served our Lord with all his
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: heart.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Thereafter Adrian, Apostle of Rome, sent word to Charles, King of France,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: that he come help him against Desir, the King of the Lombards, who much
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: tormented the Church; and Charles was as then in the town of Theodocion.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Thither came Peter, messenger of the Apostle, who said to him that the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Apostle prayed him to come defend Holy Church.  Thereupon King Charles
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: sent to the said Desir messengers to pray him that he give back to the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Holy Father the cities and other things which he had taken from him, and
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: that he would give him thereto the sum of forty thousand sols of gold in
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: gold and in silver.  But he would give way neither for prayers nor gifts.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Thereon the good King bade come to him all manner folk, Bishops, Abbots,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Dukes, Princes, Marquises and other strong knights.  And he sent to
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Cluses certain of these for to guard the passage of the ways.  Amongst
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: the which was Albins, Bishop of Angier, a man full of great holiness.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Then the King Charles together with many warriors, drew nigh to Cluses by
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: the Mount of Sinense, and sent Bernhart his uncle, and a many with him,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: by the Mount of Jove.  And the vanward said that Desir, together with all
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: his force, was already at Cluses, the which he had do dight with bulwarks
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: of iron and stone.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: But whenas Charles drew nigh to Cluses, he sent his messengers to Desir,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: praying him to give back to the Holy Father the cities which he had
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: taken; but he would nought for the prayer.  Again Charles bade him that
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: he send three of the children of the judges of Lombardy in hostage, until
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: such time as he had given back the cities of the Church, and that he
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: would betake him to France with all his host, without battle and without
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: doing any scathe.  But he neither for that, nor for aught else would
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: blench one whit.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Now when God the almighty had seen the hard heart and malice of this man;
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: and that the French were sore desirous to get them aback home, he set so
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: great fear and so great trembling in the hearts of the Lombards, that
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: they turned to flight all of them, although none chased them, and left
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: there behind them their tents and all their gear.  When that saw Charles
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: and his host, they followed them and thrust forth into Lombardy French,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Almaines, English and all other manner of folk.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Of that host were Amis and Amile, who were the first in the court of the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: King, and every way they heeded the works of our Lord, in fasting, in
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: praying, in alms-doing, in giving aid to widows and orphans, in often
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: times appeasing the wrath of the King, in suffering the evil, and
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: consoling the realm of the Romans.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Now whenas Charles had much folk in Lombardy, King Desir came to meet him
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: with his little host; for whereas Desir had a priest, Charles had a
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: bishop; whereas that one had a monk, the other had an abbot; where Desir
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: had a knight Charles had a prince; the one had a man afoot, the other a
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: duke or a count.  What should I say, where that King had one knight,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Charles had thirty.  So the two hosts fell to blows together with great
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English

author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: King Charles a very great infinity.  And after the third day’s wearing
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: whereas thereabout was the land delectable: there they refreshed them and
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: of dead there was on one side and the other, and because of this
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: together by good accord in their life-days, so in their death they were
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: not sundered.  Withal many another doughty baron was slain with them.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: But Desir, together with his judges, and a great multitude of the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Lombards, fled away and entered into Pavia; and King Charles followed
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: after them, and besieged the city on all sides.  Withal he sent into
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: France for his wife and his children.  But the holy Albins, bishop of
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: the Queen, that they should bury the dead and make there a church: and
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: the said counsel pleased much the King, and there were made two churches,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: one by the commandment of Charles in honour of St. Eusebius of Verceil,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English

author: Morris, William

text: here and there.  But on the morrow’s morn the body of Amile, and his
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: coffin therewith, was found in the Church of St. Eusebius hard by the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: coffin of Amis his fellow.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Now hear ye of this marvellous fellowship which might not be sundered by
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: death.  This wonder wrought for them God, who had given such might to His
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: disciples that they had power to move mountains and shift them.  But
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: and did do the service of them that were slain, and worshipped the said
title: Old French Romances, Done into English

author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English

text: The Tale of King Florus and the Fair Jehane
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: HERE telleth the tale of a king who had to name King Florus of Ausay.  A
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: full good knight was he and a gentleman of high lineage.  The said King
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Florus of Ausay took to wife the daughter of the Prince of Brabant, who
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: was a woman very gentle, and of great line: and a right fair maid was she
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: when he wedded her and dainty of body and fashion; and saith the tale
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: that she was but of fifteen years when the King Florus took her, and he
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: but of seventeen.  A full good life they lived, as for young folk who
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: loved together dearly: but King Florus might have no child of her,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: whereof he was sore grieving, and she also was exceeding heavy-hearted
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: thereat.  Much fair was this lady, and much she loved God and Holy
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Church, and therewith was so good almsgiver and so charitable that she
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: fed and clad poor people and kissed their feet.  And to mesel folk both
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: carles and queans was she so kind and careful, that the Holy Ghost dwelt
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: in her.  Her Lord King Florus went often to tournays in Alemain and
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: France, and in many other lands whereas he wotted of them, when he was
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: without war: much good he expended thereon and much honour he gained
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: thereby.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: But now leaveth the tale to tell of him and taketh up the word of a
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: knight who dwelt in the marches of Flanders and Hainault.  This said
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: knight was full valiant and hardy, and right trusty, and had to wife a
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: full fair dame of whom he had a much fair daughter, who had to name
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Jehane and was then of the age of twelve years.  Much word there was of
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: this fair maiden; for in all the land was none so fair.  Her mother spake
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: often to her lord that he should give her in marriage; but he was so
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: given up to the following of tournays, that he was nowise hot on the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: wedding of his daughter, and his wife ever admonished him thereof when he
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: came home from his tournays.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Now this knight had a squire who had to name Robin, and was the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: valiantest squire to be found in any land, and by his prowess and his
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: good fame oft he bore away the prize for his lord from the tournay
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: whereas he wended.  Whereon it befel that his lady thus bespake him:
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: “Robin, my lord is so given up to these tournays that I know not how to
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: speak with him, whereof I am sore at heart, for I would well that he
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: should lay pain and care to the wedding of my daughter; wherefore I pray
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: thee, for the love of me, that whenas thou seest the point thou say to
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: him that he doth very ill and is sore blamed that he weddeth not his fair
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: daughter, for there is no knight in the land how rich soever he be who
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: would not take her with a good will.”  “Lady,” said Robin, “ye have said
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: well; I will say it right well; since forsooth he troweth me of many
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: things, and so will he hereof meseemeth.”  “Robin,” said the lady, “I
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: pray thee of this business for all guerdon.”  “Dame,” said Robin, “I am
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: well prayed hereof; and wot ye that I will do to my power herein.”  “It
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: is enough,” said the lady.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: No long while after the knight betook him to wending to a tournay afar
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: from his land, and when he came there he was retained straightway of the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: fellowship, he and the knight of whose mesney he was, and his banner was
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: borne into the hostel of his lord.  The tournay began, and the knight did
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: so well by means of the good deeds of Robin, his squire, that he bore off
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: the praise and prize of the tournay from one party and the other.  On the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: second day the knight betook him to wending to his own land, and Robin
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: put him to reason many times and blamed him much in that he gave not his
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: fair daughter in marriage, and many times he said it to him, till at the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: last his lord said to him: “Robin, thou and thy lady give me no peace
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: about the marrying of my daughter; but as yet I know and see no man in my
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: land unto whom I would give her.”  “Ah, sir,” said Robin, “there is not a
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: knight in thy land who would not take her with a good will.”  “Fair
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: friend Robin, they are of no avail, all of them; and to none of them
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: shall I give her; and forsooth to no one would I give her as now, save to
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: one man only, and he forsooth is no knight.”  “Sir, tell me of him,” said
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Robin, “and I shall speak or let speak to him so subtilly that the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: marriage shall be made.”  “Certes, Robin,” said the knight, “from the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: semblance that I see of thee thou willest well that my daughter should be
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: wedded.”  “Sir,” said Robin, “thou sayest sooth, for it is well time.”
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: “Robin,” said the knight, “whereas thou art so eager that my daughter
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: should be wedded, she shall be wedded right soon if thou accord to the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: said wedding.”  “Certes, sir,” said Robin, “of a good will shall I accord
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: thereto.”  “Wilt thou give me thy word herein?”  “Yea, sir,” said Robin.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: “Robin, thou hast served me exceeding well, and I have found thee a
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: valiant man, and a loyal, and such as I be thou hast made me, and great
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: gain have I gotten by thee, to wit, five hundred pounds of land; for it
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: was but a little while that I had but five hundred, and now have I a
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: thousand, and I tell thee that I owe much to thee: wherefore will I give
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: my fair daughter unto thee, if thou wilt take her.”  “Ha, sir,” said
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Robin, “God’s mercy, what is this thou sayest?  I am too poor a person to
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: have so high a maiden, nor one so fair and so rich as my damsel is; I am
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: not meet thereto.  For there is no knight in this land, be he never so
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: gentle a man, but would take her with a good will.”  “Robin, know that no
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: knight of this land shall have her, but I shall give her to thee, if thou
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: will it; and thereto will I give thee four hundred pounds of my land.”
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: “Ha, sir,” said Robin, “I deem that thou mockest me.”  “Robin,” said the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: knight, “wot thou surely that I mock thee not.”  “Ha, sir, neither my
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: lady nor her great lineage will accord hereto.”  “Robin,” said the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: knight, “nought shall be done herein at the will of any of them.  Hold!
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: here is my glove, I invest thee with four hundred pounds of my land, and
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: I will be thy warrant for all.”  “Sir,” said Robin “I will nought naysay
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: it; fair is the gift since I know that is soothfast.”  “Robin,” said the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: knight, “now hast thou the rights thereof.”
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Then the knight delivered to him his glove, and invested him with the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: land and his fair daughter.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Then rode the knight so far by his journeys, that he came into his land,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: and when he was come thither, his wife, who was a much fair lady, made
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: him right great joy, and said to him: “Sir, for God’s sake think of thy
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: fair daughter, that she be wedded.”  “Dame,” said the lord, “so much hast
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: thou spoken hereof that I have wedded her.”  “Sir,” said the lady, “unto
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: whom?”  “Forsooth, dame, I have given her to such a man as shall never
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: lack of valiancy: I have given her to Robin my squire.”  “Robin!  Alas!”
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: quoth the lady; “Robin hath nought, and there is no knight so mighty in
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: all the land, but will take her with a good will; of a surety Robin shall
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: never have her.”  “Yea, but have her he shall, dame,” said the knight,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: “and I have invested him with four hundred pounds of my land; and all
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: that I ought to warrant him, warrant him I will.”  When the dame heard
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: that, she was much sorry, and said to her lord that Robin should have her
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: never.  “Nay, dame,” said the lord, “have her he shall, wilt thou or wilt
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: thou not; for even so have I made covenant and I will hold to the same.”
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: When the lady heard her lord, she entered into her chamber and fell
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: a-weeping and making great dole; after the dole which she made she sent
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: to seek her brothers and her nephews and her cousins germain, and showed
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: them that which her lord would do; and they said to her: “Dame, what will
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: ye that we do?  We have no will to go against thy lord, for he is a
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: knight valiant and hardy and weighty withal: and on the other hand he may
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: do with his daughter according to his will, and with his land which he
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: hath gotten withal.  So wot thou well that we will not hang shield on
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: neck herein.”  “Nay? alas, then!” said the dame, “so shall my heart never
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: have joy if I lose my fair daughter.  At least, fair lords, I pray you
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: that ye show him that if he does thus he will neither do well nor
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: according to his honour.”  “Dame,” say they, “this setting forth will we
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: do with a good will.”
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: So they came unto the knight, and when they had showed him their business
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: he answered them right courteously: “Fair lords, I will tell you what I
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: will do for the love of you; if it please you I will put off the wedding
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: in this wise as I shall tell you; to wit: Amongst you ye be rich and of
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: great lands; ye are nigh friends of my fair daughter, whom I love much.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: If ye will give her four hundred pounds of land I will set aside the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: wedding, and she shall be wedded elsewhere according to your counsel.”
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: “A-God’s name,” quoth they, “we be nought fain to lay down so much.”
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: “Well, then,” said the knight, “since ye will not do this, then suffer me
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: to do with my daughter as I list.”  “Sir, with a good will,” said they.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: So the knight sent for his chaplain, and brought thither his fair
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: daughter, and let affiance her to Robin, and set a day for the wedding.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: But the third day thereafter, Robin spake to his lord, and prayed him
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: make him a knight, whereas it was nought meet that he should take to him
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: so high a wife and so fair before he was a knight.  His lord had great
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: joy thereof, and the next day he was made knight, and the third day
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: wedded the fair maiden with great feast and joyance.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: But when master Robin was made knight he spake thus to his lord: “Sir, ye
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: have made me knight; and true it is that against the peril of death I
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: vowed me to the road unto Saint Jamesward on the morrow of my knighting;
title: Old French Romances, Done into English

text: wherefore I pray thee take it not in dudgeon if to-morrow morn I must
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: needs go my ways so soon as I shall have wedded thy fair daughter;
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: whereas in nowise will I break mine oath.”  “Forsooth, master Robin, if
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: thou leave thus my fair daughter and thus wise go your ways, ye shall be
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: will; but this wayfaring I needs must perforce.”  Whenas a certain knight
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: of the court of the lord heard these words he blamed Sir Robin much,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: whereas he was leaving his fair wife at such a point, and Sir Robin said
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: that he needs must do it.  “Certes,” said the knight, who had to name
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Raoul, “if thou goest thus to Saint James without touching thy fair wife,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: home I will give thee good tokens that I have had share of her.  Now I
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: will lay my land thereto against thine, which our lord hath given thee,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: for I have well four hundred pounds of land even as thou hast.”
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: “Forsooth,” said Sir Robin, “my wife is not come of such blood as that
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: she shall misdo against me, and I may not believe in it nowise: I will
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: make the wager with thee, if it please thee.”  “Yea,” said Sir Raoul,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: “wilt thou pledge thee thereto?”  “Yea, verily,” said Sir Robin, “and
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: thou?”  “Yea, and I also.  Now go we to my lord and make record of our
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: covenant.”  “That will I well,” said Sir Robin.  Therewith they go unto
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: the lord, and the wager was recorded, and they pledged them to hold
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: thereto.  On the morrow betimes Sir Robin wedded the fair maiden, and
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: But now leaveth the tale to tell of him and telleth of Sir Raoul, who was
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: in great imagination how he might win his wager and lie by the fair lady.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: And saith the tale that the lady held her much simply while her lord was
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: on pilgrimage, and was going to the minster with a good will, and prayed
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: God that he would bring back her lord.  But Sir Raoul pained him on the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: other hand how he might win his wager, for great doubt he had to lose his
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: land.  He spake with the carline who dwelt with the fair lady, and said
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: to her, that if she could so bring it about that she might set him in
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: have his will of her, he would give her much good, so that there would be
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: no hour when she should not be rich.  “Sir, forsooth,” said the carline,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: “thou art so fair a knight, and so wise and courteous that my lady should
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: well ought to love thee par amours, and I will put myself to the pain
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: herein to the utmost of my might.”  Then the knight drew out straightway
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: a forty sols, and gave it to her to buy a gown.  The carline took them
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: with a goodwill, and set them away surely, and said that she would speak
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: with the lady.  The knight departed from the carline, and the carline
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: abode and took her lady to task when she came back from the minster, and
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: said to her: “In God’s name, lady, tell me true!  My lord, when he went
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: to Saint Jakem, had he ever lain by thee?”  “Wherefore dost thou say
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: this, dame Hersent?”  “Lady, because I trow that thou be yet a clean
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: maid.”  “Certes, dame Hersent, so am I verily; for of no woman wot I who
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: would do such a deed.”  “Lady,” said dame Hersent, “great damage it is;
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: for if ye wotted how great is the joy that women have when they be with a
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: man who loveth them, ye would say that there is no joy so great; and for
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: this cause I marvel much that ye love not par amours even as these other
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: ladies who all love.  But if it pleaseth thee the matter is ready to
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: hand; whereas I wot of a knight, fair and valiant and wise, who will love
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: thee with a good will; a much rich man is he, and fairer by far than the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: coward recreant who hath left thee.  And if ye dare love ye may have
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: whatso ye dare ask; and so much joy shall ye have as never lady had
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: more.”  So much spake the carline by her words that the needle of nature
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: stirred somewhat.  The lady asked who the knight might be.  “Who is it,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: lady?  A-God’s name!  I may well name him.  It is the lovely, the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: valiant, the hardy Sir Raoul, who is one of the mesney of thy father; the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: kindest heart men wot of.”  “Dame Hersent,” said the lady, “thou wert
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: best let such words be; for I have no desire to misdo of my body, of no
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: such blood am I come.”  “Dame,” said the carline, “I wot well.  But never
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: shalt thou know the worthy joy when a man wendeth with a woman.”
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English

text: Thuswise abode the matter.  Sir Raoul came back to the carline, and she
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: told him how she had talked with the lady, and what she had answered.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: first stroke: and hold, here be twenty sols to buy thee a cloth to thy
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: lands, returned to the carline, and spake with her; and she said that she
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: the love of him, if she should earn her service, that she would so bring
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: it about as that there should be none in the house save he and this lady:
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: and then he might do his will on her, will she nill she: and he said that
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: he asked for nought else.  “Then,” said the carline, “ye, my lord, shall
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: castle; then can ye come to her bathing in the chamber, and may have your
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: desire of her, either with her good will or maugre.”  “Ye have well
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: said,” quoth he.

author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Abode matters thus till Sir Robin sent word that he was coming to hand,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: and would be at the house on the Sunday.  Then the carline let bathe the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: lady entered therein.  But the carline sent after Sir Raoul, and he came.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Thereafter she sent all the folk of the household out of the house.  Sir
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Raoul came his ways to the chamber and entered therein, and greeted the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: lady, but she greeted him not again, but said thus:
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: “Sir Raoul, thou art nowise courteous.  Whether wottest thou forsooth
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: that it is well with me of thy coming? accursed be thou, villain knight!”
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: But Sir Raoul said: “My lady, mercy, a-God’s name!  I am but dying for
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: grief of thee.  For God’s sake have pity of me!”  “Sir Raoul,” said she,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: “I will have no mercy in such wise that I will ever be thy darling.  And
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: wot thou well that if thou leave me not in peace I will tell my lord, my
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: father, the honour thou requirest of me: for I am none such as that.”
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: “Nay, lady, is it so, then?”  “Yea, verily,” said she.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: much joyously as a good dame ought to her lord; so abode they in joy and
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: in feast the more part of the night.  On the morrow great was the feast,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: and the victual was dight and they ate.  But when it was after dinner,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: had a black spot on her right thigh and a pearlet hard by her jewel.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: “Thereof I wot not,” said Sir Robin, “for I have not looked on her so
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: close.”  “Well, then, I tell thee,” said Sir Raoul, “by the oath that
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: When night was, Sir Robin played with his wife, and found and saw on her
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: right thigh the black spot, and a pearlet hard by her fair jewel: and
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: when he knew it he was sore grieving.  On the morrow he went to Sir
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Raoul, and said before his lord that he had lost his wager.  Heavy of
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: of him, and taketh up the word concerning his wife.

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Here saith the tale that much sorrowful was the fair lady and heavy of
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: heart, when she called to mind how she had cast her lord out of his
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: house.  Much she thought of the wherefore thereof and wept and made great
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: lineage; and he told her how and wherefore.  When she heard that, she was
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: sore grieved and denied the deed downright; but nought availed.  For it
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: is well known that shame so sore is contrary to all women, that if a
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: woman were to burn all, she would not be trowed of such a misdoing, once
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: it were laid on her.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: On the first hour of the night the lady arose, and took all pennies that
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: she had in her coffer, and took a nag and a harness thereto, and gat her
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: to the road; and she had let shear her fair tresses, and was otherwise
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: arrayed like to an esquire.  So much she went by her journeys that she
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: came to Paris, and went after her lord; and she said and declared that
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: she would never make an end before she had found him.  Thus she rode like
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: to a squire.  And on a morning she went forth out of Paris, and wended
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: the way toward Orleans until she came to the Tomb Isory, and there she
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: fell in with her lord Sir Robin.  Full fain she was when she saw him, and
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: she drew up to him and greeted him, and he gave her greeting back and
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: said: “Fair friend, God give thee joy!”  “Sir,” said she, “whence art
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: thou?”  “Forsooth, fair friend, I am of old Hainault.”  “Sir, whither
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: wendeth thou?”  “Forsooth, fair friend, I wot not right well whither I
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: go, nor where I shall dwell.  Forsooth, needs must I where fortune shall
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: lead me; and she is contrary enough; for I have lost the thing in the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: world that most I ever loved: and she also hath lost me.  Withal I have
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: lost my land, which was great and fair enough.  But what hast thou to
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: name, and whither doth God lead thee?”  “Certes, sir,” said Jehane, “I am
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: minded for Marseilles on the sea, where is war as I hope.  There would I
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: serve some valiant man, about whom I shall learn me arms if God will.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: For I am so undone in mine own country that therein for a while of time I
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: may not have peace.  But, sir, meseemeth that thou be a knight, and I
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: would serve thee with a right good will if it please thee.  And of my
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: company wilt thou be nought worsened.”  “Fair friend,” said Sir Robin, “a
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: knight am I verily.  And where I may look to find war, thitherward would
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: I draw full willingly.  But tell me what thou hast to name?”  “Sir,” said
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: she, “I have to name John.”  “In a good hour,” quoth the knight.  “And
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: thou, sir, how hight thou?”  “John,” said he, “I have to name Robin.”
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: “Sir Robin, retain me as thine esquire, and I will serve thee to my
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: power.”  “John, so would I with a good will.  But so little of money have
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: I that I must needs sell my horse before three days are worn.  Wherefore
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: I wot not how to do to retain thee.”  “Sir,” said John, “be not dismayed
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: thereof, for God will aid thee if it please him.  But tell me where thou
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William
