text: Then made they good speed to Montlhery: there John dight meat for his
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: lord and they ate.  When they had eaten, the knight slept in a bed and
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: John at his feet.  When they had slept, John did on the bridles, and they
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: mounted and gat to the road.  They went so far by their journeys that
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: they came to Marseilles-on-sea; but of war they heard no word there,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: whereof were they much sorry.  But now leaveth the tale to tell of them
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: two, and returneth to tell of Sir Raoul, who had by falsehood gained the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: land of Sir Robin.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Here telleth the tale that so long did Sir Raoul hold the land of Sir
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Robin without righteous cause, for seven years’ wearing.  Then he took a
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: great sickness and of that sickness was sore beaten down, insomuch that
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: he was on the point of death.  Now he doubted much the transgression
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: which he had done against the fair lady the daughter of his lord, and
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: against her husband also, whereby they were undone, both of them by
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: occasion of his malice.  Exceeding ill at ease was he of his wrongdoing,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: which was so great that he durst not confess it.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Came a day when he was sore undone by his sickness, so he sent for his
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: chaplain whom he loved much, for he had found him a man valiant and
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: loyal; and he said to him: “Sir, thou who art my father before God, know
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: that I look to die of this sickness, wherefore I pray thee for God’s sake
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: that ye aid me with your counsel, for great is my need thereof, for I
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: have done an ill deed so hideous and dark that scarce shall I have mercy
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: therefor.”  The chaplain bade him tell it out hardily, and that he would
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: aid him with counsel to his power; till at last Sir Raoul told him all as
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: ye have heard afore.  And he prayed him for God’s sake give him counsel,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: so great as was his misdoing.  “Sir,” said he, “be nought dismayed, for
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: if thou wilt do the penance which I enjoin thee, I will take thy
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: transgression on me and on my soul, so that thou shalt be quit.”  “Yea,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: tell me then,” said the knight.  “Sir,” said he, “thou shalt take the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: cross far over sea, and thou shalt get thee thereto within the year
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: wherein thou art whole, and shalt give pledges to God that thou shalt so
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: do: and in every place where men ask thee the occasion of thy journey,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: thou shalt tell it to all who shall ask it of thee.”  “All this will I
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: well do,” said the knight.  “Then, sir, give thou good pledge.”  “With a
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: good will,” said the knight; “thou thyself shalt abide surety for me, and
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: I swear to thee on my knighthood that I shall quit thee well.”  “A-God’s
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: name, sir!” quoth the chaplain, “I will be thy surety.”  Now turned the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: knight to amendment, and was all whole; and a year wore wherein he went
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: not over sea.  The chaplain spake to him often thereof, but he held the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: covenant as but a jest; till at last the chaplain said that but if he
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: acquitted him before God of his pledge, he would tell the tale to the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: father of the fair damsel, who had been thus undone by him.  When the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: knight heard that, he said to the chaplain that within half a year he
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: would set about the crossing of the sea, and so swore to him.  But now
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: leaveth the tale to tell of the knight, and returneth to telling of King
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Florus of Ausaye, of whom for a great while it hath been silent.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Now saith the tale that a much good life led King Florus of Ausay and his
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: wife, as of young folk who loved each other; but much sorry and
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: heavy-hearted were they that they might have no child.  The lady made
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: great prayers to God, and let sing masses; but whereas it was not well
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: pleasing to God, it might not be.  But on a day came thither into the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: house of King Florus a good man who had his dwelling in the great forest
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: of Ausaye in a place right wild; and when the queen knew that he was come
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: she came unto him and made him right great joy.  And because he was a
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: good man she confessed to him and told him all her ailing, and how that
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: she was exceeding heavy of heart, because she had had no child by her
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: lord.  “Ah, lady,” said the good man, “since it pleaseth not our Lord,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: needs must thou abide it; and when it pleaseth him thou shalt have one,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: or two.”  “Certes, sir,” said the lady, “I were fain thereof; for my lord
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: holdeth me the less dear, and the high barons of this land also.  Withal
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: it hath been told to me that they have spoken to my lord to leave me and
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: take another.”  “Verily, dame,” said the good man, “he would do ill; it
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: would be done against God and against Holy Church.”  “Ah, sir, I pray
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: thee to pray to God for me that I may have a child of my lord, for great
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: fear I have lest he leave me.”  “Dame,” said the good man, “my prayer
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: shall avail but little, but if it please God; nevertheless I will pray
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: heartily.”
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: The good man departed from the lady, and the barons of the land and of
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: the country came to the King Florus, and bade him send away his wife and
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: take another, since by this he might have no child.  And if he did not
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: after their counsel, they would go and dwell otherwhere; for in no case
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: would they that the realm should be without an heir.  King Florus feared
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: his barons and trowed their word, and he said that he would send away his
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: wife, and that they should seek him another, and they trusted him
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: therein.  When the lady knew it she was exeeeding heavy of heart; but
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: nought durst she do, for she knew that her lord would leave her.  So she
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: sent for the hermit who had been her confessor, and he came to her.  Then
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: the lady told him all the tale of the matter of the barons, who would
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: seek for their lord another woman.  “And I pray thee, good father, that
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: thou wouldst aid me, and counsel me what I should do.”  “Dame,” said the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: good man, “if it be so as thou sayest, ye must needs suffer it; for
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: against thy lord and against his barons ye may do nought perforce.”
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: “Sir,” said the good lady, “thou sayest sooth: but if it please God, I
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: were fain to be a recluse nigh unto thee; whereby I may be at the service
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: of God all the days of my life, and that I may have comfort of thee.”
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: “Dame,” said the good man, “that would be over strange a thing, whereas
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: thou art too young a lady and too fair.  But I will tell thee what thou
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: shalt do.  Hard by my hermitage there is an abbey of White Nuns, who are
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: right good ladies, and I counsel you go thither; and they will have great
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: joy of thee for thy goodness and thy high dignity.”  “Sir,” said she,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: “thou hast well said; I will do all that thou counsellest me.”
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: On the morrow King Florus spake to his wife, and said thus: “Needs must
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: thou and I sunder, for that thou mayst have no child by me.  Now I say
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: thee soothly that the sundering lies heavy on me, for never shall I love
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: woman as I have loved thee.”  Therewith fell King Florus to weep sorely,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: and the lady also.  “Sir,” said she, “a-God’s mercy!  And whither shall I
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: go, and what shall I do?”  “Dame, thou shalt do well, if it please God,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: for I will send thee back well and richly into thy country to thy
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: kindred.”  “Sir,” said the lady, “it shall not be so: I have purveyed me
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: an abbey of nuns, where I will be, if it please thee; and there I will
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: serve God all my life; for since I lose thy company I am she that no man
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: shall go with any more.”  Thereat King Florus wept and the lady also.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: But on the third day the queen went to the abbey; and the other queen was
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: come, and had great feast made her, and great joy of her friends.  King
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Florus held her for three years, but never might have child of her.  But
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: here the tale holdeth peace of King Florus, and betaketh it again to Sir
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Robin, and to John who were at Marseilles.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Here telleth the tale that much sorry was Sir Robin when he came to
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Marseilles, whereas he heard tell of nought toward in the country; so he
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: said to John: “What do we?  Thou hast lent me of thy moneys, whereof I
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: thank thee: I will give them back to thee, for I will sell my palfrey,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: and quit me toward thee.”  “Sir,” said John, “if it please thee, believe
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: me, and I shall tell thee what we shall do.  I have yet well an hundred
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: sols of Tournay, and if it please thee, I will sell our two horses, and
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: make money thereby: for I am the best of bakers that ye may wot of; and I
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: will make French bread, and I doubt me not but I shall earn my spending
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: well and bountifully.”  “John,” said Sir Robin, “I grant it thee to do
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: all as thou wilt.”
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: So on the morrow John sold the two horses for ten pounds Tournays, and
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: bought corn and let grind it, and bought baskets, and fell to making
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: French bread, so good and so well made that he sold it for more than the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: best baker of the town might do; and he did so much within two years that
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: he had well an hundred pounds of chattels.  Then said John to his lord:
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: “I rede thee well that we buy us a very great house, and that we buy us
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: wine and take to harbouring good folk.”  “John,” said Sir Robin, “do
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: according to thy will, for I grant it thee, and moreover I praise thee
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: much.”  So John bought a house, great and fair, and harboured good folk,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: and earned enough plenteously; and he arrayed his lord well and richly;
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: and Sir Robin had his palfrey, and went to eat and drink with the most
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: worthy of the town, and John sent him wine and victual, so that all they
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: that haunted his company marvelled thereat.  So much he gained that in
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: three years’ time he had gotten him more than three hundred pounds of
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: garnishment, out-taken his plenishing, which was well worth fifty pounds.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: But here leaveth the tale to tell of Sir Robin and of John, and goeth
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: back to tell of Sir Raoul.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: For, saith the tale, that the chaplain held Sir Raoul right short that he
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: should go over sea, and quit him of the pledge he had laid down; for
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: great fear he had lest he yet should leave it; and so much he did that
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Sir Raoul saw well that he needs must go.  So he dight his journey, and
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: arrayed him right richly, as he that hath well enough thereto; and so he
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: betook him to the road with three squires: and went so much by his
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: journeys that he came into Marseilles-on-sea and took lodging in the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: French hostel, whereas dwelt Sir Robin and John.  So soon as John saw him
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: she knew him by the scar of the wound she had made him, and because she
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: had seen him many times.  The knight sojourned in the town fifteen days,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: and hired him passage.  But the while he sojourned, John drew him in to
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: privy talk, and asked of him the occasion of his going over sea, and Sir
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Raoul told him all the occasion, as one who had little heed thereof, even
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: as the tale hath told afore.  When John heard that, he held his peace.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Sir Raoul set his goods aboard ship, and went upon the sea; but tarried
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: so much the ship wherein he was that he abode in the town for eight days;
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: but on the ninth day he betook him to go his ways to the holy sepulchre,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: and did his pilgrimage, and confessed him the best he might: and his
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: confessor charged him in penance that he should give back the land which
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: he held wrongfully to the knight and his wife.  Whereon he said to his
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: confessor, that when he came into his own country he would do what his
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: heart bade him.  So he departed from Jerusalem and came to Acre, and
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: dight his passage as one who had great longing to repair to his own
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: country.  He went up on to the sea, and wended so diligently, as well by
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: night as by day, till in less than three months he came to the port of
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Aigues-mort.  Then he departed from the port and came straight to
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Marseilles, wherein he sojourned eight days in the hostel of Sir Robin
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: and John, which hight the French house.  Never did Sir Robin know him,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: for on that matter he thought nothing.  At the end of eight days he
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: departed from Marseilles, he and his squires, and went so long by his
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: journeys that he came into his own country, where he was received with
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: great joy, as one who was a knight rich in land and chattels.  Thereon
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: his chaplain took him to task, and asked of him if any had demanded the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: occasion of his journey; and he said: “Yea, in three places, to wit:
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Marseilles, Acre, and Jerusalem: and he of whom I took counsel bade me to
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: give back the land to Sir Robin, if I hear tidings of him, or to his wife
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: else, or to his heir.”  “Certes,” said the chaplain; “he bade thee good
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: counsel.”  Thus was Sir Raoul in his own country a great while in rest
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: and good ease.  But here leaveth the tale to tell of him, and returneth
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: to Sir Robin and John.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Here saith the tale that when Sir Robin and John had been at Marseilles
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: for six years that John had gotten to the value of six hundred pounds,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: and they were come into the seventh year, and John might gain eke what he
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: would, and so sweet he was, and so debonaire that he made himself loved
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: of all the neighbours, and therewithal he was of good hap as he might not
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: be of more, and maintained his lord so nobly and so richly that it was
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: wonder to behold.  When the end of the seven years drew nigh, John fell
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: to talk with his lord Sir Robin, and spake thus: “Sir, we have now been a
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: great while in this country, and so much have we gained, that we have
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: hard on six hundred pounds of chattels, what of money, what of vessel of
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: silver.”  “Forsooth, John,” said Sir Robin, “they be not mine, but thine;
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: for it is thou hast earned them.”  “Sir,” said John, “saving thy grace,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: it is not so, but they are thine: for thou art my rightful lord, and
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: never, if it please God, will I change.”  “Gramercy, John, I hold thee
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: not for servant, but for companion and friend.”  “Sir,” said John, “all
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: days I have kept thee loyal company, and shall do from henceforth.”  “By
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: my faith,” said Sir Robin, “I will do what so pleaseth thee: but to go
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: into my country, I wot not to say thereof: for I have lost so much there
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: that hardly shall my scathe be righted to me.”  “Sir,” said John, “be
title: Old French Romances, Done into English

text: On a night lay Messire Thibault in his bed and pondered sore, and said:
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: and good be done to the world.”  Therewith he thought on my lord St.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English

title: Old French Romances, Done into English

title: Old French Romances, Done into English

title: Old French Romances, Done into English

title: Old French Romances, Done into English

author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English

title: Old French Romances, Done into English

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English

title: Old French Romances, Done into English

title: Old French Romances, Done into English

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English

title: Old French Romances, Done into English

title: Old French Romances, Done into English

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

text: “Sir,” said Messire Thibault, “by that wherewith thou hast conjured me

author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English

title: Old French Romances, Done into English

title: Old French Romances, Done into English

title: Old French Romances, Done into English

text: But when the Count had heard tell this adventure, much grieving was he,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English

text: me.”

author: Morris, William

text: And because of the great ire which the Count had, he called for his
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English

text: have slain him, even as he hath told it?”  “Sir,” she said, “yea.”  “And
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English

title: Old French Romances, Done into English

text: So the Count let all that be, and abode till the Court was departed.

title: Old French Romances, Done into English

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: in the tun, would she, would she not; and then let head up the tun again
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: well, that the water might not enter in no manner.  Then the Count let
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: body, and thrust the tun into the sea, and said: “I commend thee unto the

author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English

author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English

title: Old French Romances, Done into English

title: Old French Romances, Done into English

title: Old French Romances, Done into English

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English

title: Old French Romances, Done into English

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English

title: Old French Romances, Done into English

author: Morris, William

text: After dinner came the Saracens unto the Soudan, and said to him: “Sir, we
title: Old French Romances, Done into English

title: Old French Romances, Done into English

text: Malakin was a worthy, and wise, and might well come to great honour and
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: great good, and that well he might be worthied; so he said: “Malakin, by
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: my law, thou hast craved me a great thing, for I love much my daughter,
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: and no heir else have I, as thou wottest well, and as sooth is.  She is
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: born and come from the most highest kindred and the most valiant of
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: France; for her mother is daughter of the Count of Ponthieu; but whereas
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: thou art valiant, and much well hast served me, I will give her to thee
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: with a good will, if she will grant it.”  “Sir,” said Malakin, “against
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: her will would I do nothing.”
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Then the Soudan let call the damsel, and she came, and he said to her:
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: “My fair daughter, I have married thee, if so it please thee.”  “Sir,”
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: she said, “well is my pleasure therein, if thou will it.”  Then the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Soudan took her by the hand, and said: “Hold, Malakin!  I give her to
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: thee.”  He received her gladly, and in great joy and in great honour of
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: all his friends; and he wedded her according to the Saracen law; and he
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: led her into his land in great joy and in great honour.  The Soudan
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: brought him on his road a great way, with much company of folk, so far as
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: him pleased; then returned, and took leave of his daughter and her lord.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: But a great part of his folk he sent with her to serve them.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Malakin came into his country, and much was he served and honoured, and
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: was received with great joy by all his friends; and they twain lived
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: together long and joyously, and had children together, as the history
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: beareth witness.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: Of this dame, who was called the Fair Caitif, was born the mother of the
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William

text: courteous Turk Salahadin, who was so worthy and wise and conquering.
title: Old French Romances, Done into English
author: Morris, William
